`n : ℕ` is perfect if and only the sum of the proper divisors of `n` is `n` and `n`
is positive.

type: ℕ → Prop
name: Nat.Perfect
docString:
`n : ℕ` is perfect if and only the sum of the proper divisors of `n` is `n` and `n`
is positive.

For all natural numbers $n$, $1$ is a proper divisor of $n$ if and only if $n$ is a positive integer.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, 1 ∈ n.properDivisors ↔ 1 < n
name: Nat.one_mem_properDivisors_iff_one_lt
docString: For all natural numbers $n$, $1$ is a proper divisor of $n$ if and only if $n$ is a positive integer.

A positive natural number `n` can be expressed as the sum of two squares if and only if for every prime number `q` in its prime factorization, where `q` modulo 4 equals 3, the `q`-adic valuation of `n` (the highest power of `q` that divides `n`) is an even number. Note that the assumption `n > 0` is not required since for `n = 0`, both conditions are automatically satisfied; the right-hand side is true because by definition `padicValNat q 0 = 0`.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, (∃ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) ↔ ∀ {q : ℕ}, q.Prime → q % 4 = 3 → Even (padicValNat q n)
name: Nat.eq_sq_add_sq_iff
docString: A positive natural number `n` can be expressed as the sum of two squares if and only if for every prime number `q` in its prime factorization, where `q` modulo 4 equals 3, the `q`-adic valuation of `n` (the highest power of `q` that divides `n`) is an even number. Note that the assumption `n > 0` is not required since for `n = 0`, both conditions are automatically satisfied; the right-hand side is true because by definition `padicValNat q 0 = 0`.

The product of the prime factors of `n` that are less than `N` is an `N`-smooth number.

type: ∀ (n N : ℕ), List.prod (List.filter (fun x => decide (x < N)) (Nat.factors n)) ∈ Nat.smoothNumbers N
name: Nat.prod_mem_smoothNumbers
docString: The product of the prime factors of `n` that are less than `N` is an `N`-smooth number.

For any natural numbers `n` and `N`, the product of the prime factors of `n` less than `N` is an `N`-smooth number.

type: ∀ (n N : ℕ), (List.filter (fun x => decide (x < N)) n.factors).prod ∈ N.smoothNumbers
name: Nat.prod_mem_smoothNumbers
docString: For any natural numbers `n` and `N`, the product of the prime factors of `n` less than `N` is an `N`-smooth number.

This theorem states that for any natural numbers `N` and `k`, the cardinality (size) of the set of `k`-rough numbers less than or equal to `N` is bounded by the sum of the integer division `⌊N/p⌋` over all prime numbers `p` such that `k ≤ p ≤ N`. Here, a `k`-rough number is a number whose smallest prime factor is greater than or equal to `k`.

type: ∀ (N k : ℕ), (N.roughNumbersUpTo k).card ≤ (N.succ.primesBelow \ k.primesBelow).sum fun p => N / p
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo_card_le
docString: This theorem states that for any natural numbers `N` and `k`, the cardinality (size) of the set of `k`-rough numbers less than or equal to `N` is bounded by the sum of the integer division `⌊N/p⌋` over all prime numbers `p` such that `k ≤ p ≤ N`. Here, a `k`-rough number is a number whose smallest prime factor is greater than or equal to `k`.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

name: Nat.dvd_left_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

The cardinality of the set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` is bounded by `N` times the sum
of `1/p` over the primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

type:
∀ (N k : ℕ),
  ↑(Nat.roughNumbersUpTo N k).card ≤ ↑N * Finset.sum (Nat.primesBelow (Nat.succ N) \ Nat.primesBelow k) fun p => 1 / ↑p
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo_card_le'
docString:
The cardinality of the set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` is bounded by `N` times the sum
of `1/p` over the primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

A number that divides an `n`-smooth number is itself `n`-smooth.

type: ∀ {n m k : ℕ}, m ∈ Nat.smoothNumbers n → k ∣ m → k ≠ 0 → k ∈ Nat.smoothNumbers n
name: Nat.mem_smoothNumbers_of_dvd
docString: A number that divides an `n`-smooth number is itself `n`-smooth.

The cardinality of the set of `k`-smooth numbers `≤ N` is bounded by `2^π(k-1) * √N`.

type: ∀ (N k : ℕ), (Nat.smoothNumbersUpTo N k).card ≤ 2 ^ (Nat.primesBelow k).card * Nat.sqrt N
name: Nat.smoothNumbersUpTo_card_le
docString: The cardinality of the set of `k`-smooth numbers `≤ N` is bounded by `2^π(k-1) * √N`.

The cardinality of the set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` is bounded by the sum of `⌊N/p⌋`
over the primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

type:
∀ (N k : ℕ),
  (Nat.roughNumbersUpTo N k).card ≤ Finset.sum (Nat.primesBelow (Nat.succ N) \ Nat.primesBelow k) fun p => N / p
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo_card_le
docString:
The cardinality of the set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` is bounded by the sum of `⌊N/p⌋`
over the primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

The divisors of a product of natural numbers are the pointwise product of the divisors of the
factors.

type: ∀ (m n : ℕ), Nat.divisors (m * n) = Nat.divisors m * Nat.divisors n
name: Nat.divisors_mul
docString:
The divisors of a product of natural numbers are the pointwise product of the divisors of the
factors.

Nonzero divisors have valuation greater than zero.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : IsDedekindDomain R]
  (v : IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum R) (x : ↥(nonZeroDivisors R)),
  0 < IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.intValuationDef v ↑x
name: IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.int_valuation_zero_le
docString: Nonzero divisors have valuation greater than zero.

The non-zero non-`N`-smooth numbers are `≥ N`.

type: ∀ (N : ℕ), (Nat.smoothNumbers N)ᶜ \ {0} ⊆ {n | N ≤ n}
name: Nat.smoothNumbers_compl
docString: The non-zero non-`N`-smooth numbers are `≥ N`.

A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, (∃ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) ↔ ∀ {q : ℕ}, Nat.Prime q → q % 4 = 3 → Even (padicValNat q n)
name: Nat.eq_sq_add_sq_iff
docString:
A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.)

The set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` can be written as the union of the sets of multiples `≤ N`
of primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

type:
∀ (N k : ℕ),
  Nat.roughNumbersUpTo N k =
    Finset.biUnion (Nat.primesBelow (Nat.succ N) \ Nat.primesBelow k) fun p =>
      Finset.filter (fun m => m ≠ 0 ∧ p ∣ m) (Finset.range (Nat.succ N))
name: Nat.roughNumbersUpTo_eq_biUnion
docString:
The set of `k`-rough numbers `≤ N` can be written as the union of the sets of multiples `≤ N`
of primes `k ≤ p ≤ N`.

Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

type: Set.InjOn Nat.factorization {x | x ≠ 0}
name: Nat.factorization_inj
docString: Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

Nonzero divisors have nonzero valuation.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : IsDedekindDomain R]
  (v : IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum R) (x : ↥(nonZeroDivisors R)),
  IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.intValuationDef v ↑x ≠ 0
name: IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.int_valuation_ne_zero'
docString: Nonzero divisors have nonzero valuation.

If `-1` is a square modulo the natural number `n`, then `n` is a sum of two squares.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, IsSquare (-1) → ∃ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2
name: Nat.eq_sq_add_sq_of_isSquare_mod_neg_one
docString: If `-1` is a square modulo the natural number `n`, then `n` is a sum of two squares.

An additive group is `ℕ`-divisible if it `ℤ`-divisible.

type: (A : Type u_1) → [inst : AddGroup A] → [inst_1 : DivisibleBy A ℤ] → DivisibleBy A ℕ
name: AddGroup.divisibleByNatOfDivisibleByInt
docString: An additive group is `ℕ`-divisible if it `ℤ`-divisible.

The sum over primes `k ≤ p ≤ 4^(π(k-1)+1)` over `1/p` (as a real number) is at least `1/2`.

type:
∀ (k : ℕ),
  1 / 2 ≤
    Finset.sum (Nat.primesBelow (Nat.succ (4 ^ ((Nat.primesBelow k).card + 1))) \ Nat.primesBelow k) fun p => 1 / ↑p
name: one_half_le_sum_primes_ge_one_div
docString: The sum over primes `k ≤ p ≤ 4^(π(k-1)+1)` over `1/p` (as a real number) is at least `1/2`.

The proposition that a sequence indexed by integers is a divisibility sequence.

type: {R : Type u} → [inst : CommRing R] → (ℤ → R) → Prop
name: IsDivSequence
docString: The proposition that a sequence indexed by integers is a divisibility sequence.

We relate a finite product over primes to an infinite sum over smooth numbers.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : NormedCommRing R] [inst_1 : CompleteSpace R] {f : ℕ → R},
  f 1 = 1 →
    (∀ {m n : ℕ}, Nat.Coprime m n → f (m * n) = f m * f n) →
      (∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → Summable fun n => ‖f (p ^ n)‖) →
        ∀ (N : ℕ),
          (Summable fun m => ‖f ↑m‖) ∧
            HasSum (fun m => f ↑m) (Finset.prod (Nat.primesBelow N) fun p => ∑' (n : ℕ), f (p ^ n))
name: EulerProduct.summable_and_hasSum_smoothNumbers_prod_primesBelow_tsum
docString: We relate a finite product over primes to an infinite sum over smooth numbers.

The quotient norm is nonnegative.

type: ∀ {M : Type u_1} [inst : SeminormedAddCommGroup M] (S : AddSubgroup M) (m : M), 0 ≤ ‖(QuotientAddGroup.mk' S) m‖
name: norm_mk_nonneg
docString: The quotient norm is nonnegative.
